div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
SATURDAY, MAY 26, 1906.

div.head: THE MECCA RAILWAY
div.p: The news that Sultan Abdul Hamid has insisted on the Hamidieh Hedjaz line being completed at all costs within two years is of considerable importance in view of recent events in Akaba and the Sinai Peninsula. No better means could have been devised by the Khalif to restore his prestige, which recent events have somewhat impaired, and when the line reaches the Holy Places it will be safe to assume that the Moslem world will have forgotten Tabah and the surrender of May 13. Religion and strategy have dictated the Arabian policy of the Turkish Empire. The guardianship of the Holy Places constitutes the Khalif's greatest asset. Every pilgrim who visits Mecca and Medina is a witness to the Sultan's power or weakness, on his return to his fellows. If the Jeddah road is well kept and the Sherif not unduly extortionate the Sultan gains; if marauders attack the pilgrim and he, poor wretch, loses the little he has, then the sultan loses. So the railway creeps on, for Abdul Hamid knows that on it depends his empire. If he can keep Mecca and Medina, if he can flood the Hedjaz with his soldiers, no rebels of Yemen, no Ibn Saud, Emir of the Nejd, can dream of dispossessing him in Arabia. Even a foreign enemy, which might be tempted by the isolation of the Hadjaz to affront the susceptibilities of the Moslem world, would recoil from that risk were the Holy Places linked up with Damascus and Stamboul and train after train, full of the best soldiery of Islam, despatched from Eregli, Damascus, and Aleppo to succour the threatened cities from the infidel. Syria, too, stands to gain by the construction of the line. Syrian pilgrims will benefit trade, however bad the organisation of the goods department and however corrupt some of the officials attached to the line. Journeys from South to North of Syria, till recently arduoud and at times perilous, will become more frequent, and troops will always be at hand to check revolts in the Hauran or incursions of the Bedouin tribes. The Hedjaz line has already done more for the prestige of the Sultan than any number of chief victories in Thessaly; it may even restore what has been lost at Tabah and in the Yemen.

div.head: MUKHTAR PACHA.
div.p: It is impossible not to feel soe sympathy with that aged warrior Mukhtar Pacha (says the "Manchester Guardian's" London correspondent) for whose recall from Cairo a demand is going up. I think I am not far wrong in saying that if there is one thing which the Ottoman High Commissioner does not desire it is to return to the shadow of Yildiz. His relations with the Sultan are peculiarly intimate owing to his marriage to one of the princesses, and Abdul Hamid has often pressed him to come back to Constantinople, no doubt with the idea of supplying his place in Egypt with a younger man. But Ghazi Mukhtar and his family have ever made any secret of their preference for the Nile. He is, indeed, probably the happiest Civil servant in the Sultan's dominions, for, unless there has quite lately been a change, his salary, which is a sufficiently splendid one, is charged upon the Egyptian revenues and paid to him in little bags of gold monthly in advance. If it were not that his position makes him the nucleus –– often, as Lord Milner admits, "the unwilling nucleus" –– of intrigue, his career in Cairo for a not very ambitious man wth a strong taste for domesticity would have roses all the way.

Morover, it is one thing to ask for Mukhtar's recall and another thing to get it. The Convention of 24th October, 1885, under which he was sent to Egypt, is a document of first-class authority, and provides for the continuance of the two high Commissioners' duties until they consider that the situation in Egypt makes it desirable for them to "consult as to the conclusion of a convention regulating the withdrawal of the British troops from Egypt in a convenient period." Of course Sir Henry Drummond Wolff left in twelve months, and Mukhtar Pacha has remained as an intersting survival for twenty years; but our assent to his remaining it quite specific, and to ask for his recall would give the Porte a controversial apening which diplomacy may prefer to avoid. It would, besides, be quite likely that anyone else in his place would be much worse, and yet if another appointment were made it would be difficult to object to any particular person. That would be a step that would make more opportunity for trouble than the matter is worth. Mukhtar, meanwhile, is not a good conspirator, and little has been heard of him since 1892. it is probable that he will be allowed to stay in Cairo to do what seems to be expected of him by turning up at dances (sic) and receptions –– a figure rather sad to see standing about futile amond the young Civil servants and tourists, for he is a fine old man.

div.p: One case, one death, and one recovery were reported at Samalout yesterday,

div.head: The Aida.
div.p: H.H.S. Aida failed from Alexandria yesterday for the Mediterranean lighthouses.

div.head: The Sudan Prisons.
div.p: The anthropometric system of identification is about to be introduced into the Sudan.

div.head: Examination of Fikis.
div.p: A commission is to be appointed by the Ministry of Public Instruction to examine the fikis on the 16th August.

div.head: Union Artistique Francaise.
div.p: The Union Artistique Francaise will give its monthly soirée at the club premises this evening. The programme consists of musical and dramatic selections.

div.head: Secondary Education.
div.p: Of a total of 745 pupils, 291 have passed the examinations for a secondary education certificate this year. The oral examination will take place to-day.

div.head: Imperial Ottoman Bank
div.p: The directors will, it is believed, recommend a dividend of 16s. per share, equal to 8 % per annum, for the year 1905, at the annual general meeting to be held next month.

div.head: Dentistry.
div.p: Mr. A. E. Shellard, Alexandria, dental surgeon to the British troops, wishes to inform patients that during the summer months his hours will be from 9 till 5, except Satardsys, 9 till noon.

div.head: Reuter's Telegram Co.
div.p: The directors report that the balance for distribution for the year ended December 31 amounts to £4,817, including £179 brought from the last account. An interim dividend of 2 ½ per cent. was paid in October, and the directors now declare a dividend of 4s. per share equal to 25 per cent., making a total distribution, free of income tax, of 5 per cent for the twelve months, the same as in previous years. This will leave a balance of £81 to be carried forward. The dividend warrants will be payable on June 2.

div.head: Cornfield, 2,000 years old.
div.p: We have received photographs of crops of grain, sown in autumn last at the Deir in Khargeb, on a plot of land, five or six acres in area, belonging to the Corporation of Western Egypt. The crops, which consist of wheat and barley, look excellent, and were respectively reaped on April 16 and March 31 ultimo, What is phenomenal about this land is its marvellous fertility; there are positive proofs to show that the land has lain fallow since Ptolemy, 2,000 years ago, and yet despite the fact that not an ounce of manure was used, it has after this lapse of time yielded an excellent crop of wheat. The fact is worthy of a place in Egypt's history.

div.head: To Abolish the Egyptian Mosquito.
div.p: The canals and birkets in Egypt are great breeding grounds for the mosquito and it is of interest to hear of a West Indian method of extermination which could be introduced into this country. In the Barbadoes many of the waters abound in a small fish known as "millions" -presumably from their great numbers - which feeds on the larvæ of the mosquito. It is said that in the parts where the fish abounds there is immunity from mosquitoes, and that malaria is almost unknown. Experiments are to be tried by introducing the fish into other islands of the West Indies. This plan of introducing a natural enemy has proved successful in a number of cases, and the mosquito-eating fish might be introduced into other districts. If this fish really feeds largely on the larvæ of the mosquito, and if the latter have really become extinct in the district, we have the unusual case of species exterminating its own food supply.

div.head: "Architecture and Progress."
div.p: The members of the Alexandria Literary, Musical and Dramatic Society should not miss Mr. R. Williams' lecture at the Sailors and Soldiers' Institute on Monday next on the above subject. The following is a synopsis of the lecture, which will be illustrated by some much highly interesting views of buildings all over the globe: Ancient Egyptian Architecture. Whence derived, a mystery. The season of plenty again in Egypt. Great activity in building and phenomenal rise in land values. In all our doing, are we doing that is worth doing? The captains of commerce and architecture. Alexandria and architectural fantasia. Sermons in stones preached by the Egyptians while, as yet, the British were in the Palæolithic state. Supposed definition of architecture by Sanmut, an architect who practised 3000 years ago. Khammurabi's building law. Architecture not now in the "stream of educated thought." The "River of Time" and the ever swelling stream of visitors who visit th: architectural glories of the world year by year. The column fetish. The evil effect of imitations and deception in architecture. The manual workers, suggestions and conclusion.---Many of the slides to be used have been prepared from the lecturer's own drawings and photographs.

div.head: Favouritism of the Government. ,
div.p: The examination for the Egyptian Baccalaureat raised protestations- more or less justified-against a favouritism which would have been shown for the pupils of the Government schools. For modern languages the pupils of the Berlitz Schools- of Caire, 1, Sharia Kamel; Alexandria, 12, rue Rosette-have nothing to fear in the certificates, their superiority over the other candidates being too evident. [Advt].

div.head:
LORD MILNER.
BANQUET IN LONDON.
THE NATION AND ITS SERVANTS.
(Gazette's Special Service).
div.p: The banquet, which was appropriately held on the evening of "Empire Day," in honour of Lord Milner, was a magnificent, while not excessive, tribute to a great career. Mr. Chamberlain, who was in the chair, made a great speech in which he pointed out that Lord Milner and such as he sought not popular applause but were content to leave the judgement of their work to posterity. He said that Lord Milner, far from being poor, was opulent in the only kind of wealth which he valued, namely, the esteem and respect of a great body of the nation, and, far from being powerless, he was only awaiting the time when his services would again be required. Meanwhile, he was one of the Empire's great assets.

Lord Milner met with an enthusiastic reception on rising to make his reply, which was modest and rightly conceived. He said he believed that it was characteristic of the British nation, despite the exigencies of party, to deal with its servants in a spirit of broad generosity, and whilst not demonstrative in recognising their faithful services, did not go to the other extreme of noting small things done amiss but rather dealt with the merits of their service as a whole.

div.head:
BOUNDARY COMMISSIONERS SAIL.
THE DIANA AT ALEXANDRIA.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: H.H. cruiser Nour-el-Bahr sailed from Suez at noon to-day for Akaba with the Egyptian boundary commissioners.
As advised you yesterday, the cruisers Fox and Perseus sailed for Aden yesterday afternoon. They are bound to the Persian Gulf.
H.M.S. Diana, which has played a prominent part at Akaba, entered the Canal at 8 o'clock this morning bound to Alexandria.

H.M.S. Diana arrived at Alexandria early this morning from Suez, and anchored in the outer harbour. Rear-Admiral Lembton, who had been staying at San Stefano, shortly afterwards proceeded in a steam launch to join the vessel, on which his pennant was at once hoisted. The Diana then sailed, presumably for Malta.

The Diana bore the burden and heat of the day in the recent frontier dispute, having been sent on a special mission by the Commander in-Chief of the Mediterranean Fleet at the outset of the difficulty, accomplishing a delicate diplomatic mission with success, and to Lord Cromer's satisfaction. Her commanding officer, Captain R. S. Phipps Horoby, though only thirty-nine, has a record of much active work, and has before been engaged on special service in Creta and in Tangier. He also is familiar with Egyptian problems, having served in the Egyptian War in 1882, and is recognised as a promising and able young officer, following well, as opportunity occurs in the steps of his distinguished father.

div.head:
THE KHEDIVE
DATE OF DEPARTURE.
div.p: The Khedive has definitely fixed the date of his departure for Constantinople for the 6th proxo.
His Highness has decided to hold his farewell reception at Ras-el-Tin Palace on Saturday next, the 2nd Jane.

The Khedive will be one of the distinguished visitors to the Isle of Wight in Cowes week, and distinction will be lent to the visit by the presence of his yacht Mabroussa. The vessel is now nearly ready for service, and her trials will probably take place in July.

div.head:
THE CASE OF FRAULEIN MILEWSKA.
HER ARREST IN CAIRO.
div.p: The arrest in Cairo some time back of Fraulein Milewska and the events that led up to it are still occupying the attention of the Berlin law courts. This complicated case of Fraülein Milewska, who was maid of honour to Princess Amalia of Schleswig Holstein, has been occupying the Garman courts for the past six years. It received a further hearing last week.

Fraulein Milewska, as has previously been reported, is being tried for extensive embezzlement, and slander of her royal mistress. The case is going against the maid of honour, who in her turn, however, has now brought a suit against Herr von Blumenthal, Chamberlain of the German Kaiser, who effected her arrest in Cairo. She states that in order to have her arrested Herr von Blumenthal made slanderous statements concerning her to the Egyptian authorities, including allegations as to her identity as head of an Anarchist band. Fraulein Milewska also asserts that Herr von Blumenthal falsely represented in Cairo that her arrest was the direct desire of the German Kaiser himself.
It was this phase of the case, Fraulein Milewsks's accusations against the-Kaiser's Chamberlain, Herr von Blumenthal, which received a hearing last week.
The case was adjourned till further witness can be procured.

div.head:
NEW MARKET WANTED.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: The local paper "La Vérité” has recently drawn attention to many grievances at Port Said, besides pointing out several abuses in native bazaars, such as unstandardized weights and the insanitary condition of certain districts in the European quarter. Special mention is made of the custom of throwing slops into the street. One resident in Port Said has been known on occasion to carry an umbrella, when there was practically no rain, remarking to facetious enquirers, "What price the slops"! Time after time people just miss being bespattered with dirty dish and other water en passant. The lack of urinals or latrines forbids any interference with those who give offence to the more sensitive passengers unacquainted with native customs. Port Said is practically the only point in Egypt at which passengers en route to and from the East touch, to say nothing of numerous fastidious American tourists. It is a pity such an omission should have been allowed to continue so long. Residents are accustomed to these sights and possibly from the hygienic point of view there is little amiss with the present method of solving the question of sewage disposal.

With regard to the bazaar, the provision of a new market built on modern lines for the sale of fish, meat, vegetables and other goods liable to rapid decomposition in our climate would go far to remove the present unsatisfactory state of affairs.

div.head: Theft of Specie.
div.p: On the recent arrival of the S.S. Mariont, of the Khedival Mail Line, bound from Yambe, the Captain reported the loss of specie to the amount of £6,000. An enquiry instituted by the Governor in Suez was successful not only in securing the culprits, but also their booty.

div.head: Tennis Club Dance,
div.p: On Friday evening the Tennis Club gave a very successful dance in the Eastern Exchange attended by a number of members, their friends, and officers of the Minerva.

div.head: Man Overboard.
div.p: In passing through the Canal last week, one of the crew of the East African liner Prinz Regent fell overboard, but was fortunate in being rescued as owing to the storm the ship had to moor at the psychological moment.

div.head: New Austrian Lloyd Steamers,
div.p: A contract has been signed by the Austrian Lloyd Co. with the Austrian Government which necessitates the building of new fast steamers of the estimated value of two millions.

div.head: An Innovation.
div.p: The custom of painting the name in large letters in the centre of the hull of many foreign ships seems to have recommended itself to at least one English line coming from West Hartlepool. The English custom of inscribing the name at one end of the ship in letters indistinguishable at any distance must often cause inconvenience to people unacquainted with the designation of the ships as represented by the painting of the funnel or the special flag of the company.

div.head: A BEHERA OFFSHOOT.
div.p: An important new land company is being formed to take over fourteen thousand feddans belonging to the Bahera Company. The capital of the company, which is in the hands of a strong group of local capitalists, will be about £600,000.

div.head: HELLENIC AGENCY.
div.p: The Hellenic Government has appointed M. Kalergis, an official of the Greek Ministry of Foreign Affairs, as acting Diplomatic Agent and Consul General in Egypt, instead of M. Geunadie, M. Kalergis arrived at Alexandria this morning from Greece, and is leaving tomorrow for Cairo Mr. Alexandropoulo, Consul General at Jerusalem, or Mr. Papadiamantopoulo, attaché to Prince George in Crete, will probably be appointed Hellenic Consul General and Diplomatic Agent when Mr. Gennadis definitely quits the post.

div.head: UPPER NILE SURVEY.
div.p: About 300 more kilometres of the preliminary levelling and surveying of the Nile Valley between Khartoum and Wady Halta have been completed in addition to the 480 kilometres done by the beginning of March. The cataracts are to be surveyed in detail, so as to furnish the Ministry of Public Works with a series of accurate large-scale maps of that part of the river valley

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Leyland S.S. Cestrian sailed hence last evening for Liverpool direct.
The Ellerman S.S. Belgravian sailed last night from Malta and is due here on Tuesday morning with general cargo.

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN NILE STEAMERS AND HOTELS CO.
div.p: At the annual general meeting of the above company, which was held in Cairo yesterday, it was decided to distribute a dividend of six and a-half per cent.

In regard to the company's land at Boulac, we understand that the area embraces about 8,000 square metres, which, at a very conservative estimate of its total value, should be worth at the very least £50,000.
The following is the report of the directors for the past year's working up to the 30th ult.

In preparing their sixth annual report and balance sheet the directors, though satisfied that the general business of the company has on the whole been maintained, have felt the absence of any special sources of profit which made last year one of exceptional prosperity and enabled them to declare a larger dividend than usual. A further reduction of profit has to be recorded under the heading of freight : the return on the capital invested in this branch of business has fallen to a point inconsistent with any further reduction in rates. The directors hope that the present tariff may be maintained, but, should the competition in rate cutting be further indulged in, they may be obliged to adopt a policy which, while entailing some temporary loss and inconvenience on their shareholders, will effectively put an end to the practice.

Experiments have been made during the past year in the construction and equipment of sailing barges and their employment in river and canal traffic. The great difficulty of controlling native crews whose riverain origin makes them desirous of prolonging, rather than of ending their voyages, is largely responsible for results, which, if not altogether constituting a failure, cannot be regarded as otherwise than a qualified success. The doubt attaching to the outcome of any experiment seems to justify the policy of the directors in refusing to embark in capital expenditure of any magnitude without first assuring themselves, as far as such a thing is possible, that it will be permanently remunerative. It may, and does mean, that a portion of the capital of the company remains unengaged. It is however possible to find temporary remuneration for capital outside the business of the company, and in this connexion the directors are able to point to the successful employment of the reserve fund which has produced a very considerable profit. This fund, which after last year's additions amounted to L.E. 12,000, has now been brought up to L.E. 17,000 by the premium derived from the issue of 5,000 shares to the Hamburg-America Line. The investment, as last year, appear in the balance sheet at cost price ; the depreciation on the Crédit Foncier shares is counterbalanced by the appreciation in the value of the Menzaleh shares, but no account has been taken of either.
AGREEMENT WITH HAMBURG-AMERICA LINE.

The arrangement arrived at with this important Company, of which details were given at the extraordinary general meeting, is one which will, the directors believe, be to the advantage of the shareholders. A considerable economy is expected from the concentration of the European agencies in the hands of the Hamburg-America Line, while the additional tourist traffic which they should secure, should contribute largely to the success of the new steamboats which are to be put on the Nile. There boats are being built in England and will, it is hoped, be ready for the coming tourist season.

Want of space in the Company's yard at Boulac and the difficulty of providing in so limited a space an ares both for the requirements of modern and efficient workshops and of a ware-housing depôt, led the directors to seek for a suitable site elsewhere ; the price of land in the near vicinity of Cairo suitable for the purpose is now almost prohibitive, but they are happy to say that they have obtained from the Ministry of Finance a lease of three feddans of land at Shoubra for a period co-extensive with the existence of the company. This site, although somewhat distant, is, nevertheless, well adapted to the company's requirements by virtue of its long trontage on and depth of water in the Nile channel. A considerable outlay will have to be incurred in erecting adequate premises and workshops. The directors, however, hope to be able to provide for this by the sale of a portion of their site at Boulac. After writing off the value of the present workshops and such plant as cannot be removed and making provision for the new premises, it is expected that a considerable surplus will be available. This will be devoted to further strengthening the position of the company by the creation of those special funds without the protection of which no navigation company can be said to be properly safeguarded.

The Directors propose to pay a dividend of 6 ½ % and to carry forward a balance of L.E. 1,801,365 m/m. After provision for depreciation and maintenance, there remains to be distributed on this season's working alone, a sum of L.E. 6,847,539 m/m from which the directors propose to pay a dividend of 5% LE. 5,850,000 m/m leaving a balance of L.E. 997,539 m/m

row.cell: 10 % to Board according to Art. 36 of Statutes
Carried forward to Profit and Loss Account next year

div.head:
THE VICTORIA COLLEGE.
ITS INCEPTION.
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Dear Sir,--You will excuse the liberty I take in thus writing you these lines, but seeing that H.E. Lord Cromer laid the foundation stone of the New Victoria College yesterday, I thought perhaps you would like to know the history of the first establishing of this school, in which you and every Englishman take such a great interest.

By birth I am not an Englishman, but I have been in connection with the Britishers for nearly 50 years, coming amongst them as a boy, and all my thoughts, my interests and feelings are with that race. I am now about 64 years of age, and whatever I have, even to my existence, I owe to them, and I do not regret it, because they have treated me always as one of their own countrymen.

I was sent out here by the Church of Scotland Mission Society in the year 1877, I believe. I began and continued my work earnestly but it was most difficult as there was no English schools everything was foreign. French, Italian and German schools there were, and no one seemed to have any sympathy with the English, who by other nationalities seemed to be hated and despised. The above nationalities taught only their own language in their own schools. Consequently I began to worry the life out of the late lamented Sir Ch. Cookson and the late lamented Canon Davis, of St. Mark's Church for nearly 5 years. These two gentlemen I was so often with them, that I was taken as part and parcel of them, they were great and true friends of mine. I asked them, why don't you get the English Government to build a good English school here, which is so greatly needed ? The reply was that the English Government did not build schools in foreign countries, and told me I should not worry myself to death about the matter, that my heart was too soft, and if I did not take care my head would be the same. I did not care, I thought if the English Government would not help with a day school, I would by the help of my two friends' financial help start a night school. I did, and had over 150 adults and boys. I was obliged to pay English teachers and I asked Professor Alf. Griffen and another Englishman who has since died at Constantinople to come and help me. Syd. H. Carver, Esq.. Judge Lionel Sanders, Sir. Ch. Cookson, apd Canon Davis provided me with the means to pay the teachers and to pay all expenses, which I kept up for over 3 years and it was a great success. In the end I was sorry to give the night school up owing to Sir Ch. Cookson leaving Egypt as the means at my disposal after he left were not sufficient to keep it going.

The year before he left though I was so persistent, and not going to be daunted I would not leave the good Sir Charles alone, until I had got by hook or by crook a day school, until in desperation be said, "Well, Rudolph, if you can encourage some rich Jews to take an interest in the school you can have your heart's desire and we will make it a good one." I was delighted. I brought Clement Aghion to Sir Charles Cookson, and we talked the matter over, especially upon finance Clement Aghion got his relative Giuseppe Aghion and Baron Menasce to join, and the Victoria College was first established by Sir Ch. Cookson, Clement Bohor, and Gioseppe Aghion, Baron Menasce, and the late Canon Davis, and I pride myself upon being the originator of the scheme, when I amongst the many others behold the foundation, the corner stone of which H.E. Lord Cromer laid, one of the finest schools in Egypt.
Professor Alfred Griffen can bear me out and testify to what I have said to be true, with regard to the establishment of the school.-- Believe me, etc.
P. Rudolph

div.head:
NUNGOVICH HOTEL CO.
A SUCCESSFUL COMPANY.
REPORT FOR THE YEAR.
div.p: The annual general meeting of the shareholders of the George Nungovich Egyptian Hotels Company, Limited, will be held this afternoon, when the following report of the results of the past year working up to 30th ulto., will be presented to the shareholders :-
Nous avons l'honneur de vous soumettre les comptes du septième exercice social de notre Compagnie.

Après acquittement d'ana somme de L.E. 6907, 696/1000 pour réparation et remplacements, de tous les frais d'exploitation et d'ad. ministration, et d'une somme de L.E. 8046, 951/1000 pour amortissement d'obligations, dépréciation des mobiliers, matériels et installations, ainsi que du solde total des frais de premier établissement, il reste un bénéfice net pour l'exercice de : L.E. 25.481, 791.

Sur cette somme il y a lieu de prélever un premier dividende de 5 % aux actions soit sur 27.500 actions de £4=£5,500, L.E. 5,362, 500, Ce qui laisse un solde de L.E. 20.119,291. Conformément aux prescriptions des statuts sur ce montant il doit être fait un prélèvement de 10% pour la réserve L.E. 2,012. Il est attribuée selon l'article 36 des statuts dix pour cent au Conseil d'Administration L.E. 1.810, laissant un montant disponible de L.E. 16.297,291, auquel il y a lieu d'ajouter le solde reporté de l'année dernière soit LE 3,007,603 ; formant en total de L.E. 19.304,894. Nous vous proposons de distribuer un dividende complémentaire de 15% soit, 16.087,500, et de reporter à nouveau L.E. 3.217.394.

Ainsi que nous l'avons exposé à l'Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire du 17 Avril de cette année, nous avons acquis au cours de l'exercice l'immeuble enclavé au côté Nord du Savoy Hotel, qui avec la parcelle de l'ex-propriété Sabet Pachs achetée l'année dernière sur le côté Est, nous permet d'agrandir notablement le Savoy Hotel et son Restaurant.

En vertu de l'arrêt favorable que nous avons obtenu de la Cour d'Appel mixte sur l'instance en préemption qai avait été formée à l'encontre de notre Société, l'achat du Mena House est devenu définitif.

En conséquence des décisions prises en Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire du 17 Avril dernier le Capital est porté à Lst. 148.000 ; d'autre part, en tenant compte de la prime sur le prix d'émission des 9.500 actions nouvelles, et du prélèvement sur les bénéfices de l'exercice écoulé, la réserve atteindra la somme de Let. 98.000.
Vous avez à approuver les comptes qui vous sont présentés, en donner décharge à vos Administrateurs et voter sur le dividende proposé.
Vous avez en outre à élire un Administrateur en renouvellement partiel du Conseil. L'Administrateur sortant et M. Ernest Stangen; nous vous rappelons qu'aux termes des statuts il est rééligible.
Vous avez aufin à nommer un Censeur pour l'exercice 1906 7 et à fixer son indemnité.

div.head: THE GHARBIEH LAND COMPANY LIMITED.
div.p: La question du jour dans le monde de la Bourse est le refus que vient d'opposer la Corporation des agents de change à la demande d'admission à la cote de la Gharbieh Land.
D'après l'article 22 des statuta de la Corporation des agents de change nous voyons :

En dehors des valeurs déjà reconnues et dont le tableau signé par le Président de la Corporation est affiché à la Bourse, aucune nouvelle valeur ne pourra être admise à la cote officielle de la Corporation, si son introduction n'a pas été préalablement étudiée par le comité, pois votée par l'assemblée générale.

Les Sociétés constituées en vue d'une industrie nouvelle pour le pays ou dans un bat de spéculation ou désignant dans leur objet un programme qui ne serait pas limité ou qui serait trop général ne pourront être admises qu'après une période de fonctionnement de une a trois années et après appréciation du bilan annuel, du bénéfice distribué et de la réserve établie.

Cet article institue le pouvoir exclusif des agents de change qui peuvent toujours accuser une société, si sérieuse soit-elle, d'avoir on bat de spéculation pour la renvoyer d'année en année, jusqu’au jour où des preuves irréfutables de sa bonne constitution les obligent de l'accueillir.

La Gharbieh Land est une des sociétés les plus sérieuses que nous ayons, son objet ost "l'achat, l'amélioration, l'exploitation et la vento de terrains notamment dans la province de Gharbieh"; en un mot c'est une société dans le même genre que la Behera aveo un capital inférieur.

THE NATAL RISING.
IMPERIAL TROOPS READY.
VIGOROUS OFFENSIVE MEASURES.

div.p: The Imperial troops here have been ordered to hold themselves in readiness in view of the serious situation in Zululand. (Reuter)

There has been a practical armistice for several days past, while the chiefs were conferring together, but Bambaata's agents have persuaded them to continue their resistance. Colonel Mackenzie is now preparing vigorous offensive measures. (Reuter)

div.head: STUDY OF TROPICAL DISEASES.
div.p: Sir Alfred Jones, president of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, has received from the Secretary General of the Congo Free State a letter in which it is stated that the Government of the Congo Free State has resolved to bear the expense which was occasioned by the visit of the members of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine during their sojourn on the Congo. These expenses, which include in a general way the maintenance of the expedition, the salaries of the attendants, and transport expenses, amount to £1,421. The Government desires by this decision to show its sympathy with the philanthropic work undertaken by the School of Medicine and with the spirit in which its members acquitted themselves in their mission to the Congo. The King of the Belgians has sent a very complimentary letter contributing £2600, in addition to the large sum he has already given to the funds of the school.

div.head: LANCASHIRE COTTON COMMISSION'S RETURN.
div.p: The members of the Lancashire Cotton Commission, which went to America some two months ago to inquire into the economic conditions of cotton cultivation and ascertain whether it is possible to obtain permanent improvements in the handling of cotton shipped to Lancashire, arrived in Liverpool last week by the White Star steamship Baltic. One of the commissioners, Mr. W. J. Orr, stated that the tour had been most successful! in every respect. Cotton-growing in the southern States was a very prosperous industry and there were great prospects of development. Millions of acres were fit for cotton cultivation the only difficulty being the problem of black labour.

div.head:
OUR CONSULS.
SOME VITAL QUESTIONS.
div.p: 1. Ought we to appoint foreigners, or British subjects and protégés who are not British-born, to be our Consuls ?
II. What are the qualifications necessary to a Consul in order that he may be able to further the interests of his country ?
III. Ought the Consul to be a diplomatist, or a commercial, business man?

These three questions are questions of the hour; they are of burning importance, not so much to our present, but to our future position in the markets of the Levant, where already our keen competitors are, thanks to a better Consular system, wresting from us market after market. The United States Government, with their grasp of things, have spotted this vital need of an efficient Consular service, and there is now a movement on foot to remedy many of the evils which American trade suffers in the East, at the hands of others.

The time has come when, if we are not to go to the wall, the British Foreign Office must follow the example set by the more practical American and German, and put to itself the questions above quoted. I had better answer them in the order they come:

I. In a letter some time ago, I alluded to the evil effects of employing foreigners for handling British goods ; I must now extend this remark to our Consuls, and ask: Is the foreigner, even though be may be of British nationality or enjoy British protection, the right men to represent our most sacred interests abroad: the sort of man who would be likely to sacrifice himself for the benefit of our commerce ? I say no. He may be a good man-in the majority of cases the foreign Office appoints men of unquestionable probity and honour, and who are often recommended by not only the official, but the merchant class of the town or port to which they are nominated, and in which mayhap they have commercial interests. But British they are not. By birth, by sympathy, by interest they are aliens. They will do their duty in so far as concerns a Pharisaical observance of the ritual of the Official Clock and Calendar, but nothing more. Why should they ? The English pay them, and in return they do for them a certain amount of work, but what inducement, except when it concerns their interests, is there for putting themselves out of the way, overtime, to push our trade? There are in Turkey 20, Greece 8, Crete 3, Consular officials whose names, unless Whitaker's Almanac has misspelt them, are decidedly foreign ; in Germany, the lion's den, there are 21, mostly Germans, and in Italy 22, while in Austria, also another important base for commercial operations in the Levant, the Consul-General is of foreign race. Even in far Abyssinia, which is an outpost of our trade in Africa, there are two Consular representatives who are certainly not Englishmen. The plea of the Foreign Office in defending these appointments may be economy, the lack of competent Englishmen available locally for the posts, or the advantage of employing natives whose knowledge of their own country, languages, and customs would be superior to that of the Englishman. If such are their real motives, then they are wrong.

It is false economy to commit your trade interests abroad to men who are connected with the soil, either by blood or sympathies, or, as in some cases with which I am familiar, by the more substantial ties of commerce. It is better to pay an Englishman a good salary, and have the satisfaction of feeling that your trade is going ahead, than to have a foreigner who can use his official position and information to increase, not the interests of the country he represents, but the annual turnover of some private concern which he or his relations may be running.

Then, if competent Englishmen are not available locally, they should be sent out from home. But this is not the case. There are plenty of honest British-born merchants and agents who know both the languages and the people who would only be too willing, if only for the dignity, to serve their country in such an official capacity, and uphold the dignity of Great Britain's name. True, these honest British-born merchants might fall under the suspicion, as with the native Consul, of serving their own ends with the official seal. But this is hardly likely in the case of a bona fide patriot, and even if his official information were useful to his private business, it were better that an Englishman, rather than an outsider, should benefit by it. The advantage, too, of employing a native because of his superior knowledge of his own country is a one-sided argument, which does not show whether that especial knowledge will benefit the country he represents or the one he lives in ; nor does it imply that he is equally well posted in the commercial ways of the one as he is of the other. I will therefore dismiss this first question, and proceed to the next :-

What are a Consul's necessary qualifications? First and last, commercial knowledge, which few of them possess. After an unprofitable cramming in the classics, they enter the Consular career with a notion that their duties consist not in encouraging, but in drawing up retrospective tablets of Great Britain's exports into such and such a country with conventional footnotes that are based solely on those figures ; they do not explain the reason for each a decline or such an increase, which from the merchant's and manufactorer'e point of view is the most important thing, and they do not enter into details of which the whole consists and which it is most essential to analyse in order to understand the sum total.

But unless the Consul is a commercial man, how can he know the way of making that analysis? The fault is with the Foreign Office who appoint him. While our commercial rivals, the Germans, Americans, and Austrians, have dependencies of the Foreign Office which are practically training colleges for their Consuls and to which every consul is responsible, our own Foreign Office has no such immediate hold. The Board of Trade is an independent institution and can exert but an indirect influence on those who supply it with returns. If we are to compete successfully with our ever-multiplying rivals, we must have men independent of all except the Foreign Office, who by their profound experience may be able to help us to cope with a competition which is becoming all the more keen every day. We must copy the example of Germany, which has a splendid Commercial Department connected with her Foreign Office, thoroughly equipped with every sort of information both supplied to and by its consuls abroad. I once heard one of the most influential and reliable authorities on British trade in the Levant (Sir J. W. Whittall) describe this Department. "Marvellous" was the adjective he used. Moreover every manufacturer of Germany is in touch with this Department, which, in its turn, supplies them with the samples sent by their Console, and which they were asked to imitate at a lower price than that ruling on the market abroad. If therefore we are to compete successfully; an intimate connection must be established between the agent and Consul abroad, and the Foreign Office and manufacturer at home. The main point however is the commercial education of the Consuls ; to obtain this he must go through a special course of study in a Commercial College which shall specially fit him for the country to which he is to be nominated.

There is, while I think of it, another point which is noteworthy. Why is it that a Consul is more or less a fixture? If he moves at all, it is to be transferred from one centre where he may be acquiring useful knowledge to an entirely new sphere at the Antipodes. Instead of globe-trotting, the Consul would get a much better insight into the trade of a country by regularly touring in it, than by collecting second-hand information at the capital, which any merchant or journalist can do, if only he care to.

Lastly. The third question is one which bears upon one anomaly which in the interest of trade had better be abolished. I refer to the two-fold character of the Consul's office. Ought he or ought he not to be a diplomatist : Yes and no. In the case of a country like Egypt which is subject to peculiar political conditions, this two-fold character is an utter essential of our policy. But elsewhere, and in Turkey especially, where politics are dangerous tools in unskilled hands, there is much to be said for and against.

In Constantinople the diplomatic character of the Consul is completely eclipsed by the presence of the Embassy, so that he should be able to devote himself entirely to matters of trade. Unfortunately this is not the case. The Consul-general considers himself to be an adjunct of the Embassy, and consequently much valuable time is lost between British merchants and their authorities in defining the attributes, provinces, and powers of the Consular jurisdiction. In the capital, therefore, the Consul has no political importance, or ought not to. In those towns of the Empire which are remote from the ægis of the Embassy, and where the Consul is authorised to exercise discretionary powers, it is difficult to define where the consularship ends and the diplomatist begins. More than once, and especially in the Lebanon, Armenia, and Macedonia, the interference of the Consul has been regarded in the light of political intrigue by the authorities, and under such circumstances trade is not likely to expand as it should, for the Turk is extremely suspicious and does his best to put obstacles in the way of the Consul on every possible occasion, whereas if the Consul were to confine himself solely to trade he would undoubtedly receive every assistance. In the interests of British trade, I repeat, it were well that this two-fold character were dissolved, and that discretionary powers were conferred on a Special Political Resident who would be wholly independent of the Consulate, and who would be responsible alone to his Embassy.
XENOS.

div.head:
CRICKET.
CAIRO v. ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: Played at the Alexandria ground, and won by Alexandria after a very good finish by 13 runs. Alexandria won the toss and sent in Maclaren and Capt. Palmer. The former, after being let off early, scored freely, as did his companion, and soon caused changes in the bowling. The fielding was very fair and the bowling steady on the whole, so that to score 90 in an hour and a half was very creditable. At 99 Maclaren was taken at cover for a good innings of 50. Rome then found his way through Mainprice's defence, the batsman being all but bowled and prettily stumped by Drower. Capt. Palmer was taken by Rivers Smith at cover for 63- very steady and stylish innings--and at lunch four wickets had fallen for 121. After lunch Peel and Street, though rather uncomfortable, took the score to 142, when Street was run out by Rivers Smith. A collapse followed. Peel got out l.b.w.- a doubtful decision in the opinion of some of the players. Barnard was prettily stomped and to make a long story short the side were out for 178. For Cairo, Rome and Graves did best with the ball.

The Cairo innings was a replica of the Alexandrian. Rome and Graves, aided by some luck, got going and put on 89 for the first wicket, when Rome was taken at slip for a freely hit and attractive half century. Graves fell to a bad stroke and a good catch directly afterwards. Then came a collapse. Two batsmen were run out-one very narrowly-and nine wickets fell for 137. Capt. Bostock, who had been playing a very steady game, then made a fine attempt, aided by Sergeant Simpsop, to pull the match out of the fire. Simpson at last fell to a catch at the wicket when only 13 runs were required and the match was over. It was a very keen game and on the day's form there was little to choose between the sides. Mention must be made of Drower's admirable wicket keeping for Cairo. Scores :
ALEXANDRIA

div.head: PORT SAID SPORTING CLUB.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, - The prevailing instinct among the Egyptians--we speak in the broad sense--is, never do today what can be done tomorrow. It may be that the assimilations of many races has tended to this end, or it may be the deleterious effect arising from the waters of the Mediterranean being ozoneless. Whatever the causes that have instilled this keynote in the Egyptian character, it is unfortunate that the European, and more especially the British, element should allow themselves to become infected by these undesirable influences. However, such is the case, and particularly can it be noted at Port Said. Everyone wakes up tired in the morning, sleeps all the afternoon, and yawns throughout the evening. Speak to any members of the committee about the new Sporting Club, for instance, and each one will refer you to the other. Meanwhile the sand is enclosed on four sides by a railing, the gates of which are forever locked. There is one point, however, we must give credit to the committee for. They have the instinct for getting, or rather trying to get at, the subscriptions.

When objections are raised to paying for the support of the derelict a committee meeting is held in the shades of the evening, and a resolution is passed that "something must be done." We rather think they mean that somebody must be done. For the next morning applications for subscriptions are spread around Port Said. This is what has to be contended with here. Nobody knows anything at all, and the committee know less.

Yet there is a rumour,--but we must be careful of rumours ; Port Said lives on them- that things are righting themselves, and we may yet hope for a New Sporting Club in the course of a few years, provided the committee will exercise any little energy they may possess, under which circumstances we have authority for stating Schweppe's would be delighted.

If it would not be considered infra dig., we should like to make the suggestion, that while the committee are vegetating the gates might be unlocked for the benefit, and further comfort, of the natives.--I am, etc..

When the catarrh has become systemic, – that is, when it has been allowed to spread through the entire system, it is a difficult disease to cure.
Physicians do not always understand it and some of them do not care to treat it. Hence the inability of a great many patients to find a cure.

The correct thing to do for these cases is to make use of some internal, systemic catarrh remedy,– one that will reach every internal organ of the body and exercise a healing, strengthening and soothing effect upon the mucous membranes lining these various organs
Such a remedy has been found in Peruna.
As Mr. Cholette states, his testimonial is not the first one written in behalf of Peruna, the remedy which brings permanent relief in all cases of systemic catarrh.

div.head: LÉS SOCIETES ANONYMES EGYPTIENNES
div.p: Comme suite à notre article d'hier, relatif au rapport présenté par le Contentieux de l'Etat du Gouvernement au sujet des parts de fondateurs dans les sociétés anonymes, nous reproduisons l'article suivant d'un de nos confrères du Caire :

Ce que le Contentieux suggère et ce que le Conseiller Financier désire, c'est que les parts de fondateur ne soient créées que dans des entreprises où il y aurait des apports à rémunérer : apports en nature ou apports en idées.

Or, la rémunération des apports se fait ad moyen d'actions d'apport, le cas est prévu dans toutes les législations et l'article 11 du Règlement Egyptien da 6 mai 1899 est entièrement consacré à ce type d'actions.
Les inventions utiles (breveté, etc.) rentrent dans la catégories des apports, il n'y a pas lieu de trouver un mode de paiement spécial pour les inventeurs.

Les parts de fondateur ne sont pas des actions d'apport, comme leur nom l'indique ; ce sont des parts réservées aux fondateurs en rémunération du travail de constitution de la Société et comme une sorte de prime aux premiers capitaux engagés. M. Jacques Vavasseur, dans le Dictionnaire du Commerce, de l'Industrie et de la Banque, parle de la part de fondateur dans les termes suivants :

On rencontre souvent aussi dans les Sociétés par actions des titres d'une nature spéciale et qu'on désigne sous le nom de parts de fondateur : 00 sont des titres représentant des parts de bénéfices attribuées, lors de la constitution de la Société, aux fondateurs. Ces parts de fondateur ne sont pas réglementées, par la loi ; tonto liberté est donc laissés en parties pour leur création, et les règles concernant les actions de capital ou d'apport leur sont étrangères ; cependant, comme ces parts de fondateur constituent des avantages particuliers, lear création doit être vérifiée et approuvée par l'assemblée générale lors de la constitution de la Société.
Ce type d'action n'est pas tout à fait inconnu en Egypte ; on s'en est occupé lors de l'élabɔra tion la règlement du 6 mai 1899 dont l'article 10 est ainsi conçu :
Il ne peut être créé de parts de fondateur? que par l'acte constitutif de la Société.
Les parts de fondateur ne confèrent à leur possesseur accon droit de vote dans les Assemblées générales.
Los parts de fondateur n'auront droit à une quotité des bénéfices que quand les actions de capital auront touché au moins 5 %
La quotité qui pourra leur être alloué par les statuts de peat pas dépasser la moitié de cet excédent.

Lors de la dissolution de la Société et après remboursement au pair des actions de capital, le solde de l'actif social sera réparti dans les mêmes proportions entre les actions et les parts de fondateur
Toutes les dispositions relatives aux parts de fondateur spot applicables aux actions dites de dividende.
On savait donc parfaitement, il y a sept ans, ce qu'étaient les parts de fondateur dans une société. Est-il possible que l'on ait, depuis, totalement perdu la notion de ce que ce titre représente ?

div.head:
Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Notre Circulaire n'a pas paru hier, le marché des valeurs au Caire et à Alexandrie étant resté fermé à l'occasion de la fête de l'Ascension.
Avant-bier, le taux de l'escompte privé à Londres a été réduit de 1/8 à 3 1/2 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé, le même jour, de 1/8 à 89 3/4, prix auquel il a clôturé bien. L'Unifie, la National Bank, l'Agricole et la Daïra sont restées in. variées avant-bier et bier. Seule, la Delta Light a baissé, en ces deux jours, de 1/4 de livre & 11 7/8.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a réactionné, avant bier, de 1 franc à 773. La Banque d'Athènes est demeurée inchangée à 151. Hier, la Bourse de Paris était close.

Réconforté peut-être par le repos imprévu d'hier, notre marché des valeurs a montré, ce matin, dès le début de la séance, beaucoup d'activité et, par moments, d'excellentes dispositions. L'animation s'est principalement manifestée dans le groupe das Hôtele, où les Nangovich et les Baehler, fortement soutenus, ont donné lieu à plusieurs transactions. Divers autres titres ont acquis également une avance.
La National a clôturé plus forme à 26 1/32. 1/16. L'Agricole s'est maintenue à 9 13/16. La Banque d'Orient s'est inscrite à 135 et le Comptoir Financier à 5 13/16 l'action ancienne.

L'action Crédit Foncier est restée à 775.776; l'obligation à lots 1886 a progressé à 323. La Behera a avancé à 36 37. L'action Immobilière a gagne-8 francs à 374 ; la part de fondateur A, par contre, fléchit à 595. L'action Enterprise and Development s'est raffermie à 11 13/16-7/8.

La Nile Land & encore perdu 5/8 14 1/4. L'action Land Allotment est restée délaissée à 3 7/16; la part de fondateur a raculé à 137 pour finir à 110. L'action Bourse Khédiviale du Caire a baissé à 115. Les privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie ont avancé à 190 et les dividendes à 340.
Les Nungovich ont été poussés jusqu'à 16 5,32 pour clôturer à 16 1/32. Løg Baehler ont avancé de 5 à 5 3/:6.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Estates ont été traités à 1 9/16 à l'ouverture, pour finir à 1 5/8. Les Delta Land, qui ont déterminé de fortes transactions, ont passé de 3 25/32 à 3 29/32 pour clôturer à 3 7/8.
Les Now Egyptian ont fait 28.sh. 3. Les Markets sont revenus à 26 sh. 9 et les Oasis a £ 1.
Nous sommes en mesure de confirmer la nouvelle que nous avions enregistrée sous toutes réserves dans notre Circulaire de mardi dernier.

Les négociations pour la fusion de l'Egyptian Land and General Trust Ltd. (Hooker) avec la Delta Land Co. sont reprises, et on s'attend à ce qu'elles aboutissent cette fois définitivement. Ainsi que nous l'avions dit, l'échange des titres se ferait comme bait: six actions Hooker contre une action Delta Land.
Il est probable que, conformément au désir exprimé par les actionnaires, un ou deux administrateurs de Trost seront appelés à faire partie du Board de la Delta Land.
Nous détachons d'une lettre de Londres, en date du 17 Mai, les lignes suivantes concernant la situation monétaire :

"La crainte que l'on éprouvait il y a quelques jours de voir la Banque d'Angleterre élever son taux d'escompte s'est sensiblement atténuée, mais elle n'a pas tout à fait disparu. Certes, l'exode de l'or vers l'Amérique a considérablement diminué et tout porte à croire qu'elle finira par toucher à son terro e. Mais, si le loyer de l'argent sur le marché libre est appelé à décroitre, il n'est guère vraisemblable que la Banque abaisse son taux d'escompte au-dessus de 4 % avant d'avoir renforcé sa réserve. Celle ci est encore inférieure de £ 4 millions et demi à ce qu'elle était à cette époque en 1905, et les directeurs persistent à estimer que les circonstances ne permettent pas de se départir de la prudence la plus attentive tant que l'incertitude contingers à régner en ce qui concerne l'avenir du marché monétaire.

"Cet état de choses exerce, naturellement, son influence an Stock Exchange, qui reste dans l'inaction. Les quelques tentatives de reprise qui se sont produites ces jours derniers en vue de soutenir le marché n'ont pas été heureuses ; elles ont plutôt contribué à accentuer la lourdeur et la réaction."
On a démenti, ici, la nouvelle, donnée récemment par les journaux d'Alexandrie, suivant laquelle il serait question d'un projet de fusion entre l’Egyptian Hôtels Co. et la Nungovich Hotels Co.
Mentionnons, à titre de curiosité, quelquesnes des bases sur lesquelles on asseyait cette combinaison :

Suppression du Grand Continental Hotel et vente du terrain sur lequel il est construit; remplacement du Gezireh-Palace par an petit hôtel de grand luxe; agrandissement da Savoy et da Shepheard's ; construction d'un grand hótel anx Pyramides, eto.

Ajoutons pour compléter cet exposé, que, malgré le démenti publié au Caire, un journal d'Alexandrie répète, à la date d'hier, que des pourparlers seraient réellement engagés et que la fusion pourrait bien être conclue à Londres dans le courant de l'été.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd' hui a midi et demie)
Le marche tres anime a donne lieu a de grosses transactions qui occasionnent une hausse de presque toutes les valeurs
L'Agricole est demandee a 9 7/8
La National Bank se releve tres sensiblement a 26 5/16 en hausse de 5/16 sur hier.
Les Eaux du Caire gagnent 1 franc a 117 et les jouissances 2 francs a 262.
La Delta Land est tres echangee et cote en cloture 4 7/33.
Les Estates avancent de 1/32 a 1 11/16, les Urbaines de 3/32 a 6 1/4.
L'opinion est tres optimiste et le mouvement a la hause qui s'affermit aujourd'hui a beaucoup de chance de s'acceutuer encore davantage. On prevoit meme pour Lundi une forte reprise.

div.head:
The 'Allenburys' Diet
A Light Nourishment for General Use
For Invalids, Dyspeptics & the Aged
Allen & Hanburys Ltd., Lombard St., London.
div.p: The "Allenburys" DIET is a complete milk and farinaceous Food, easy of assimilation, most agreeable to take, simply and quickly made. It is recommended in place of ordinary milk foods, guel, etc., and whilst acceptable to all as a light nourishment, it is particualrly helpful to Dyspeptics, Invalids and the Aged. In the sick-room it will be found invaluble and it is easily and quickly made, the addition of boiling water only being necessary.

The "Allenburys" DIET is readily digested by those who are unable to take cow's milk and it is particularly serviceable in convalescence. When taken as a light supper diet it will be found to promote tranquil and refreshing sleep. Although this DIET is a food for ADULTS and is entirely distinct from the "Allenburys" Foods for Infants, yet it is also of great value as a restorative food for young children, especially during convalescence.

div.head: Cotons
div.p: Dans notre revue de Vendredi dernier nous avons exprimé l'opinion que le Juillet, en prenant la place du Mai, devait faiblir et perdre pour ainsi dire tout naturellement l'équivalent du report, mais ni nous, di pos frères en pessimisme n'aurions jamais pensé à la possibilité de voir se produire un mouvement de baisse a088i rapide et surtout aussi ridiculement exagéré que celui que-nous avons en an commencement de cette semaine. C'est petit à petit et dans des proportions moindres que le fait devait se vérifier à potro avis, et c'est tout d'on coup que nous avons en cet effondrement des cours de la vieille récolte, que rien ne justifiait, et qui a été une véritable surprise pour tout le monde.

Il y avait bien en l'air un peu de lourdeur et peut-être même un peu de malaise parmi les petits spéculateurs, mais était-ce un motif suffisant pour provoquer cette forte de panique qui s'est intensifiée dans la matinée de mardi et qui a fini par faire tomber le Juillet à 20 3/8? Et le plus drôle est que les 3/4 de tallari perdus ce jour-là étaient, pour ainsi dire, de superflu, car avec la baisse de 5/8 des denx jours précé dents chacun croyait que tout était dit et la meilleure prouve que nous pourrions fournir de cette conviction est que le commerce d'exportation lui-même avait profité de la première reculade pour acheter, d'autant plus que depuis Vendredi les ordres de loi faisaient pas défaut, ni de l'Angleterre, ni da Continent. Dans tous les cas, cette piètre tenue du marché aura on le bon côté de faciliter énormément les affaires pour l'étranger, voire même de les développer, et c'est à cette circonstance que l'on devra d'avoir eu ce balayage qui en définitive aura assaini le marché.

Les quantités ainsi enlevées aux mains faibles et aux timorés ont été assez conséquentes et l'on s'explique dès lors très facilement la reprise qui a suivi et qui n'a fait que s'accentuer. Il semble pourtant qu'il y a un défaut dans les agissements actuels du parti haussier et ce défaut, qui lui est habitué, c'est l'exagération qui commence à poindre : on a baissé trop vite et on a l'air maintenant de vouloir remonter plus vite encore, comme si quelque fait nouveau et important était surgi pour stimuler les intéressés à la ha080 et leur mettre en tête, pour la dixième fois au moins, ces idées de 25 tallaris et ce qui s'ensuit.

Certes, aujourd'hui le marché est allégé et plus dégagé, mais il y a quand même encore du coton à vendre et il serait malheureux d'en entraver le placement à la filature par une hausse intempestive qui sera accueillie par de la résistance de sa part. Il est incontestable, et nous somme des premiers, à l'admettre, qu'il y a encore des besoins à couvrir pour le restant de la campagne et que la position statistique est favorable aux badesiere, mais pourquoi devrait on gâter les choses et ne pas donner le temps matériel à la consommation de s'habituer aux nouveaux prix que nous avons déjà atteints. Si on l'éloigne derechef ne fût ce que pour quelque tempe, on sentiment de découragement de tardera pas à se faire jour chez nous et le risque d'une autre débandade Bera toujours là menaçant. Mieux vaut donc être modéré, car en fin de compte ce ne sont que les mouvements graduels qui réussissent généralement et l'expérience du passé devrait nous servir pour l'avenir. Le Caire vient tout récemment de subir cette épreuve et que de regrets ne sont ils pas maintenant exprimés par la spéculation de la capitale de n'avoir pas su mettre une limite à son engouement et à son avidité !

Mais trêve de réflexions et parlons du marché Les diverses étapes par lesquelles nous sommes passés pendant la semaine peuvent se résumer de la façon suivante : Samedi, baisse de 21 3/4 à 21 11: ; londi, clôtare 21.1/8 et mardi chate à 2011/32, minimum de la journée, et point auquel il y a en arrêt, quoique sans amélioration immédiate. Et de fait, ce n'est qu'à partir de mercredi que la reprise a commencé et cela après que l'on a vu que la dernière filière de Mai, qui n'a été que de 7000 Cantare environ, n'avait eu aucun effet déprimant sur le marché. Ce jour-là, la hausse s'est élevée à 3/8 et elle a été suivie le lendemain par une autre de 3/32, quimalgré son peu d'importance a été considérée comme un indice favorable pour l'avenir. Toutefois, l'opinion prédominante était que la progression ascendante ne pouvait plus continuer d'are façon marquée; aussi la surprise ce matin a-t-elle été bien grande quand tout d'on coup on a va le cours, de 20 13/16,passer à 21 1/4 pour finir à 21 S.S.

Quoi qu'il en soit, c'est sur cette dernière cote que la semaine s'est terminée nous donnant, comme bilan, une reprise d'un tallari plein du point le plus bas et une perte totale réduite 3/8 de tallari pour toute la semaine.

Vu les circonstances, pareil résultat n'est pas du tout mauvais, mais, comme il est dit plus haut, il serait peut être bon de s'arrêter un peu, car en somme il n'y a pas de découvert à exploiter et c'est sur la consommation seule que nous devons compter.

La nouvelle récolte a dû nécessairement subir quelque peu l'influence de la situation du Juillet, mais au fond elle a montré une excellente tenue au moment le plus critique, elle n'a fléchi que jusqu'à 16 9/16 et cela en dépit de toute la pression exercée par les baissière. Quant au cours de clôture de ce jour, il est de 16 7/8, ce qui représente une hausse de 3/32 depuis vendredi dernier. Eu peu de mots, nous avons là une preuve indiscutable que la spéculation se jette de plus en plus sur le Novembre et que plus que jamais les idées de soutien prévalent. Quant à la finale, c'est une question qui ne pourra être décidée que plus tard, quand on verra comment se présentent les récoltes et que la vieille récolte aura cessé de fournir un certain appui aux idées de ceux qui sont intéressés comme acheteurs.
Comme activité, le marché des contrats n'a rien laissé à désirer.

Le marché du disponible, malgré une on deux journées d'animation relative, est resté comme ensemble très calme ; d'ailleurs, il y a si peu de coton cftert en disponible, que l'exportateur & plas de col vönance à racheter ses contrats pour servir sa clientèle ear son propre stock, chaque fois que l'occasion s'en présente

Pour ce qui est des prix, les modifications à la cote officielle de ce jour vous présentent une baisse de 1/4 à 1/2 tallari pour les Mitafifi et de 3/8 pour les provenances Haute Egypte. tandis que les Abassi et les loannovich restent nominalement à leur précédent niveau.

Les exportations de la semaine ont fini par dépasser dege z sensiblement les prévisions et il va de soi que c'est la baisse, qui nous a valu de nouvelles affaires, qui est la cause de l'augmentation. Le chiffre total est de 7700 balles, contre 8000 et comme résumé, notre stock est de cr. 785,000, coutre 1 320,000. Ce n'est pas là le point faible de la situation du coton égyptien !

Pour la semaine prochaine on s'attend à de bonnes expéditions, mais on ne saurait encore parler de quantités approximatives. L'année dernière, pour la même période, nous avons eu 10,000 balles d'embarquées.

Liverpool a été assez bon pour nos cotons, quoique, en définitive, il n'y ait rien en d'extraordinaire comme ventes.- Pour ce qui est des prix, le disponible est resté immuable à la cote de 10 1/2, tandis que les fluctuations des futurs y ont été fréquentes, le mai tombant de 10 20/64 à 10 pence, pour remonter à 10 15/64.
Par grand chose à dire de l'américain, si ce n'est qu'il n'a pas été bien actif et que le résumé des variations de la semaine présente 5 points de baisse - tant sur le spot que sur les futurs.

D'Amérique il n'y a rien en de bien intéressant : après avoir prêobé la baisse, on y parle de nouveau de hausse et c'est Price qui, après quelques jours de répit, la préconise sans fournir d'explications à l'appui de son opinion.
Les derniers avis ad sojat de la nouvelle récolte sont plus favorables et cela doit être réellement le cas, sans cela le Sud ne continuerait pas à vendre.

Chez nous il y a désaccord sur les progrès de la plante. En général, on admet qu'elle a formé de bonnes racines, ce qui est excellent pour l'avenir, mais on trouve en même temps qu'elle est trop peu développée et qu'elle aurait besoin d'un peu plus de chaleurs.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Les recettes ont été petites, pour ne pas dire insignifiantes, mais comme de leur côté les exportations n'ont en aucune importance, l'influence de ces deux faits a été nulle sur le marché. La baisse donc que nous avons eue et qui s'était élevée à P.T. 5 doit être attribuée exclusivement à la situation des contrats. D'ailleurs, la reprise de P.T. 6 que nous avons eue depuis lors est une preuve évidente que cette assertion est la vraie. Dernière cote P.T. 71 pour le disponible.

Sur les contrats Dous avons en notre panique en règle et c'est à la peur qui s'est emparée de la petite spéculation que nous devons d'avoir va le cours de P.T. 66 1/2 pour le Jaillet, mais après l'allégement des positions qui en a été la conséquence, l'échéance en question est remontée à P.T. 72 25/40. Hull qui n'avait faibli à £6 8/9 qu'à cause de nous est remonté en deux bonds à £6 16/3, ce qui a fait comprendre, mais un peu trop tard à la spéculation, que la baisse venait d'ici et non de l'extérieur.

En somme, la situation est bonne et comme les besoins existent toujours, la perspective en reste favorable. Quelques ventes, relativement importantes, ont été faites ces jours-ci tant en Angleterre que sur le Continent et les prochaines expéditions de Juin constitueront à coop fûr un encouragement pour les détenteurs de la vieille récolte.
Il faudrait seulement savoir éviter l'écueil de l'exagération.

La nouvelle récolte avait fléchi au-dos8008 de P.T. 62, mais avec la reprise du juillet elle a hausse de nouveau : P.T. 63 15/40. On n'y signale pas encore d'affaires pour l'Europe, mais il semblerait que Hull serait disposé à commencer sur la base de £6 5/- pour les 3 mois novembre-janvier.

div.head: Feves.
div.p: Les arrivages n'ont cessé d'être intermittents et peu importants, mais il est à supposer que la hausse à P.T. 105 provoqués par l'amélioration des contrats induira l'intérieur à nous envoyer un peu plus de marchandise. Intempestive on non, la bangsa est là et rien n'empêche d'en profiter. Sar septembre-octobre, contrats, il y a en un peu de demande spéculative, mais on dirait qu'on a fait tout exprès de pousser les cours qui sont aujourd'hui affichés de 108 à 110. Pourtant, malgré ce haut niveau les vendeurs à découvert n'osent pas s'engager, ce qui fait que les attraits sont rares et parement occasionelles.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIÈRE
div.p: Encore une semaine d'attente qui nous a apporté des heures d'espoir et également de lassitude. La reprise que nous espérons n'a point voulu se faire et cette semaine a été d'une lourdeur désespérante.

Rien, pourtant, ne justifie l'apathie qui a envahi notre marché et y règne en maitresse. Au contraire, tout aurait prévalu, sinon pour une reprise très importante, tout au moins pour redonner aux affaires un cours normal
L'incident d'Akabah terminé à la satisfaction générale, aucun nuage à l'horizon politique, la révolte apaisée en Russie; il ne reste qu'une explication plausible: l'exode estival.

Les capitalistes, possédant de gros dossiers auraient, paraît-il, passé des ordres de vente considérables et l'offre ne se trouve plus, ainsi, en raison directe de la demande. Cela nous étonne, car il est difficile d'admettre que de gaité de cœur, on accepte de perdre une somme importante pour le simple plaisir d'aller faire un tour en Europe ou d'alléger op portefeuille que l'on croit trop chargé. Et quand bien même, ces capitalistes auraient pu se résoudre à se débarrasser de quelques valeurs, de peu d'importance, susceptibles de grandes fluctuations, cela n'expliquent pas cet état qui persiste et dont les grosses valeurs souffrent tout autant, pour ne pas dire davantage, que les petites.

Nous nous abstiendrons donc, aujourd'hui, de chercher une explication à l'accalmie du marché de cette semaine, nous contentant de répéter à nos lecteurs ce que nous leur avons toujours dit: cette situation ne peut durer, car cette baisse des valeurs n'est basée sur rien ; une reprise qui remettra les choses au point est imminente.
En attendant nous allons faire le bilan de la semaine.
Samedi le marché a donné lieu à quelques affaires; de gros ordres d'achat ont produit une hausse plus ou moins sensible, hausse qui de se continue malbearensement pas les jours suivants.

Lundi le marché est revenu à son apathie des derniers jours de la semaine passée. A part quelques petites valeurs qui ont été échangées la cote générale éprouve une dépréciation assez sensible. Cette lourde ır. continue le mardi et le mercredi faisant fléchir graduellement presque toutes les valeurs.

Vendredi, le marché a semblé se ranimer, de nombreux échanges ont été opérés, produisant ainsi une hausse partielle. Ce mouvement continuera, espérons-le ; il nous a fait entrevoir pour samedi un marché intéressant qui sera peut être le commencement de la reprise tant attendue.

Nous croyons, utile de donner à nos lecteurs le compte rendu de l'assemblée des créanciers de la Société générale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte, qui a en lieu au tribunal mixte du Caire le 22 courant à 5 heures, aux fins de voter l'admission on le rejet du concordat judiciaire.

Cette assemblée a eu lieu sous la présidence de M. Tuck, juge-commissaire, et en présence de MM. Sampaolo, Horschitz e Roox de Vence, syddio et co-syndics; de MM. Barois et Arbib, administrateurs de la société, et de Mtres Carton de Wiart, R-zé, Guilbaumon, Merzbach, Bahari, etc...
Les propositions concordataires présentées à cette assemblée étaient les mêmes que celles faites aux créanciers à la réunion du 10 février dernier.
L'admission de concordat judiciaire a été votée à l'unanimité des créanciers représentés.
Les créanciers admis étaient au nombre de 32,783, produisant pour la somme de L.E 1.498.147.
Le nombre des créanciers votants a été de 22.769 produisant pour la somme de L.E. 1.496 470.
Quatorze créanciers seulement produisant pour L.E. 1.677.316 étaient absents.
Le ministère des finances qui a voté le concordat était représenté par M. Pietri.
L'homologation du concordat judiciaire a été renvoyée à l'audience du 2 juin prochain.
Nous empruntons aux comptes présentés à l'examen des créanciers les passages suivants :
Récapitulation du compte d'exploitation générale
Compte de profits et pertes de l'exerciee 1904 1905

div.p: Miss A. M. Steadman, living at 130, Cambridge Road, Kilborn, London, England, says :- "I wish I could tell you how thankful I am for the good Doan's Backache Kidney Pills have done me. They have saved my life. Before I began using them, the doctor said I couldn't live another three months, but that was a year and a quarter ago, and I'm as well to-day as ever I was in my life.

"Before using Doan's Pills I was suffering from Bright's disease and dropsy. My body was so swollen that I couldn't get my clothes or boots on; the pains in my back were fearfully agonizing, and I could hardly breathe. Though I went under hospital treatment, and had the best of medical advice, I kept getting worse and worse until I began with Doan's Pills. I cannot speak too highly of this medicine, for it did me good from the first, and although it was a year and a quarter ago that I was cured, I am still in splendid health.”

Women who suffer from pain or dull ache in the back, loins or sides, from dizzy spells, rheumatic twinges, urinary trouble, gravel, sciatica, flatulence, headaches-women who are nervous, irritable, moody-women who can't stoop, can't eat, can't sleep, and who seldom smile-are recommended to try Doan's Backache Kidney Pills ; for Doan's Pills help the kidneys to purify the blood and drive out the dissolved or crystallised poisons that - when kept back in the body by clogged kidneys -cause fatal kidney complaints such as dropsy, stricture, Bright's disease, and diabetes.
Doan's Kidney Pills are sold by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T. per box, or 71 P.T. for 6 boxes ; or they may be had direct from the general agent for Egypt,-Max Fischer, Mousky Street, Cairo.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up,” and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
